fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Strict universes for Grothendieck topoi
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @unpublished{gratzer-shulman-sterling-2024-universes, author = {Gratzer, Daniel and Shulman, Michael and Sterling, Jonathan}, year = {2024}, month = may, doi = {10.48550/arXiv.2202.12012}, eprint = {2202.12012}, eprintclass = {math.CT}, eprinttype = {arXiv}, note = {Unpublished manuscript}, title = {Strict universes for Grothendieck topoi}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Hofmann and Streicher famously showed how to lift Grothendieck universes into presheaf topoi, and Streicher has extended their result to the case of sheaf topoi by sheafification. In parallel, van den Berg and Moerdijk have shown in the context of algebraic set theory that similar constructions continue to apply even in weaker metatheories. Unfortunately, sheafification seems not to preserve an important realignment property enjoyed by presheaf universes that plays a critical role in models of univalent type theory as well as synthetic Tait computability. When multiple universes are present, realignment also implies a coherent interpretation of connectives across all universes that justifies the cumulativity laws present in popular formulations of Martin-LÃ¶f type theory.

We observe that a slight adjustment to an argument of Shulman constructs a cumulative universe hierarchy satisfying the realignment property at every level in any Grothendieck topos. Hence one has direct-style interpretations of Martin-LÃ¶f type theory with cumulative universes into all Grothendieck topoi. A further implication is to extend the reach of recent synthetic methods in the semantics of cubical type theory and the syntactic metatheory of type theory and programming languages to all Grothendieck topoi.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Most practical programming languages have side effects: state, input-output, errors, etc.
Monads capture the structure of side effects (Moggi, Wadler).
State means being able to interact with the computerâ€™s memory; references or pointers govern access to a location in memory.
The syntax of state varies along three axes:

html:p.html:em: What kind of things can be stored in memory cells?
When can these memory cells be allocated?
What equations hold of stateful computations?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Storing only integers or other first-order data.

Extensionality of models lost when moving to higher-order storage.
An extreme point in the design space...
Deeply impredicative: heap contains elements of arbitrary types.

An equational theory of higher-order store in which reads to the heap leave behind â€œbreadcrumbsâ€.
Consider two implementations of an â€œcounterâ€ object:

fr:mainmatter.html:p: They appear to be indistinguishable. Indeed, they are â€œobservationally equivalentâ€!

Observational equivalence is an extremely weak property: indistinguishability under observations of ground type only. It would be great if we could instead deduce an absolute equation: \color {red}\vdash \mathsf {posCounter} \equiv \mathsf {negCounter} \colon \mathsf {Counter} (No cheating: we want â€œstandardâ€ models without extensional collapse or logical relation.)
We add two additional rules to the equational theory of guarded higher-order dynamic allocation.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: S., Gratzer, and Birkedal (2022) found synthetic denotational semantics for guarded higher-order dynamic allocation in an impredicative version of guarded dependent type theory (iGDTT).
Guarded recursion needed to solve the domain equation; impredicativity needed to define the monad (b/c \mathsf {Heap} is large).

Our main observation is that a slight variation on SGBâ€™22 suffices to model univalent reference types, so long as both \mathbf {FinSet} and \mathbf {Set} are both univalent universes in the sense of Voevodsky.

html:ol.html:li: Univalence of \mathbf {FinSet} implies the LAYOUT UNIVALENCE rule.
Univalence of \mathbf {Set} implies the CELL UNIVALENCE rule.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We therefore need an impredicative version of guarded homotopy type theory.
We define iGHoTT to be the extension of Martin-LÃ¶fâ€™s intensional type theory by the following additional features:

html:ol.html:li: homotopy type theory: the univalence axiom
guarded recursion: later modality \mathord {\blacktriangleright } and solutions to guarded fixed points
a univalent impredicative universe, i.e. a universe \mathcal {S}\in \mathcal {U} closed under families of \mathcal {S}-small types indexed in a \mathcal {U}-small type.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In iGHoTT, we can define a model of univalent reference types. The real question is whether we can find a model of iGHoTT.
Palombi and S. (2023) have contributed a modular method for building models of (non-univalent) guarded dependent type theory over an arbitrary base topos. As applied by SGBâ€™22:

html:ol.html:li: Any realisability topos \mathcal {E} contains an impredicative universe \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {E}}.

Then the relative presheaf topos \mathcal {F} :\equiv {\mathopen {}\left [\mathbb {O}^{\mathsf {op}},\mathcal {E}\right ]\mathclose {}} is a model of guarded recursion and contains an impredicative universe \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {F}} defined from \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {E}} by Hofmannâ€”Streicher lifting.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We have not gotten around to adapting the SGBâ€™22 model of iGDTT to obtain a model of iGHoTT, which is much more complicated.

html:ol.html:li: Let \mathbb {A} be a partial combinatory algebra.
Let \square be a suitable internal cube category in \mathbf {PER}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}, and let \mathbb {O} be an internal well-founded order in the same.

Then the category of internal presheaves of assemblies {\mathopen {}\left [{\mathopen {}\left (\square \times \mathbb {O}\right )\mathclose {}}^{\mathsf {op}},\mathbf {Asm}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}\right ]\mathclose {}} is expected to form a model of iGHoTT{}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Impredicative HoTT via cubical assemblies due to Awodey et al. and studied by Uemura, Swan.
Guarded HoTT via \square \times \mathbb {O} due to Birkedal et al. (2019).

fr:title.text: A more canonical model of iGHoTT?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A more canonical model of iGHoTT?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Even if internal presheaves of assemblies on \square \times \mathbb {O} works, the resulting model will be uncanonical from the {\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-categorical standpoint.
For example, if \mathbb {O}=\omega , we shall not have defined the â€œinternal (pre)-{\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-topos of treesâ€ in cubical assemblies.

More canonical approach would be to take internal presheaves on any \mathcal {S}-small well-founded order \mathbb {O} internal to the {\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-category \mathcal {E} presented by {\mathopen {}\left [\square ^{\mathsf {op}},\mathbf {Asm}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}\right ]\mathclose {}}. This may introduce coherence problems that we are currently unprepared for.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: SGBâ€™22 were not the first to combine guarded recursion with realisability to model higher-order dynamic allocation; see Birkedal, StÃ¸vring, and Thamsborg (2010).

However, op.cit. relied on a specific realisability model based on an untyped domain model of a stateful language; in contrast, the model construction of SGBâ€™22 applies uniformly for any pair {\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {E},\mathbb {O}\right )\mathclose {}}.
Thus SGBâ€™22 showed that realisability is inessential: if we find any other viable source of impredicative universes besides realisability, SGBâ€™22 would apply there too.

fr:title.text: On the relationship between QTT and STC

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: On the relationship between QTT and STC

fr:mainmatter.html:p: I have been thinking again about the relationship between quantitative type theory and synthetic Tait computability and other approaches to type refinements. One of the defining characteristics of QTT that I thought distinguished it from STC was the treatment of types: in QTT, types only depend on the â€œcomputationalâ€ / unrefined aspect of their context, whereas types in STC are allowed to depend on everything. In the past, I mistakenly believed that this was due to the realizability-style interpretation of QTT, in contrast with STCâ€™s gluing interpretation. It is now clear to me that (1) QTT is actually glued (in the sense of q-realizability, no pun intended), and (2) the nonstandard interpretation of types in QTT corresponds to adding an additional axiom to STC, namely the tininess of the generic proposition.

It has been suggested to me by Neel Krishnaswami that this property of QTT may not be desirable in all cases (sometimes you want the types to depend on quantitative information), and that for this reason, graded type theories might be a better way forward in some applications. My results today show that STC is, in essence, what you get when you relax the QTTâ€™s assumption that types do not depend on quantitative information. This suggests that we should explore the idea of multiplicities within the context of STC â€” as any monoidal product on the subuniverse spanned by closed-modal types induces quite directly a form of variable multiplicity in STC, I expect this direction to be fruitful.

My thoughts on the precise relationship between the QTT models and Artin gluing will be elucidated at a different time. Today, I will restrict myself to sketching an interpretation of a QTT-style language in STC assuming the generic proposition is internally tiny.

Let \mathscr {Q} be an elementary topos equipped with a subterminal object \P \hookrightarrow \mathbf {1} inducing an open subtopos \mathscr {E}\simeq {\mathscr {Q}}_{/\P }\hookrightarrow \mathscr {Q} and its complementary closed subtopos \mathscr {F}\hookrightarrow \mathscr {Q}. This structure is the basis of the interpretation of STC; if you think of STC in terms of refinements, then stuff from \mathscr {E} is â€œcomputationalâ€ and stuff from \mathscr {F} is â€œlogicalâ€.

We now consider the interpretation of a language of (potentially quantitative) refinements into \mathscr {Q}. A context \Gamma is interpreted by an object of \mathscr {Q}; a type \Gamma \vdash A is interpreted by a family A\to \bigcirc {\Gamma }; a term \Gamma \vdash a : A is interpreted as a map \Gamma \to A such that \Gamma \to A \to \bigcirc \Gamma is the unit of the monad.

So far we have not needed anything beyond the base structure of STC in order to give an interpretation of types in QTTâ€™s style. But to extend this interpretation to a universe, we must additionally assume that \P is internally tiny, in the sense that the exponential functor {\mathopen {}\left (-\right )\mathclose {}}^\P is a left adjoint. Under these circumstances, the idempotent monad \bigcirc \equiv j_*j^* : \mathscr {Q}\to \mathscr {Q} corresponding to the open immersion j : \mathscr {E}\hookrightarrow \mathscr {Q} has a right adjoint \square : \mathscr {Q}\to \mathscr {Q}, an idempotent comonad.

As \bigcirc \equiv j_*j^* is the exponential functor {\mathopen {}\left (-\right )\mathclose {}}^\P , its right adjoint \square is therefore the â€œroot functorâ€ {\mathopen {}\left (-\right )\mathclose {}}_\P that exhibits \P as an internally tiny object.
Although \square lifts to each slice of \mathscr {Q}, these liftings do not commute with base change; this will, however, not be an obstacle for us.

We will now see how to use the adjunction \bigcirc \dashv \square to interpret a universe, either for the purpose of interpreting universes of refinement types, or for the purpose of strictifying the model that we have sketched. Let \mathcal {V} be a (standard) universe in \mathscr {Q}, e.g. a Hofmannâ€“Streicher universe; we shall then interpret the corresponding universe of refinements as \mathcal {U}:\equiv \square \mathcal {V}. To see that \mathcal {U} classifies \mathcal {V}-small families of refinements, we compute as follows:

html:ol.html:li: A code \Gamma \vdash \hat {A} : \mathcal {U} amounts to nothing more than a morphism \hat {A}:\Gamma \to \square {\mathcal {V}}.
By adjoint transpose, this is the same as a morphism \hat {A}^\sharp : \bigcirc {\Gamma }\to \mathcal {V}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Thus we see that if \mathcal {V} is generic for \mathcal {V}-small families of (arbitrary) types in \mathscr {Q}, then \mathcal {U} \equiv \square \mathcal {V} is generic for \mathcal {V}-small families of type refinements, i.e. types whose context is \bigcirc -modal.
Finally, we comment that the tininess of \P is satisfied in many standard examples, the simplest of which is the SierpiÅ„ski topos \mathbf {Set}^{\to }.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Weeknotes 2025-W15 â€º Two papers to appear in LICS â€™25 â€º With Andrew Slattery: Hofmannâ€“Streicher lifting of fibred categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This year, Thomas Streicher (born 1958) passed away from cancer. Thomas was one of the Greats of dependent type theory and he also wrote an excellent textbook on domain theory for denotational semantics, but much more importantly he was kind and curious and patient and always made time for young people. While I was still finding my place in the community, Thomas was very generous to me with his time and advice, and he sent me many papers to referee.

Although Thomas made many contributions to dependent type theory, domain theory, realisability theory, and category theory, he is most known to type theorists for two thingsâ€”both in collaboration with the late Martin Hofmann: the groupoid interpretation of type theory and the eponymous Hofmannâ€“Streicher universe lifting construction. Andrew and my paper pertains to the latter.

The idea of Hofmannâ€“Streicher lifting has to do with universes, which are â€œtypes of typesâ€ (typically defined in such a way as to avoid paradoxes). Martin-LÃ¶f type theory usually includes universes in order to be able to quantify over (small enough) types; in the simplest models of Martin-LÃ¶f type theory, types are interpreted as sets and so Martin-LÃ¶fâ€™s universes are interpreted as certain sets of sets, such as Grothendieck universes. But it is important to be able to interpret the language of type theory in more sophisticated worlds than set theory: for example, in presheaves (which are functors from a fixed category C into Set). What Hofmann and Streicher did is show how to transform any universe of sets into a universe of presheaves!

Although Hofmann and Streicherâ€™s construction worked well and had good properties, they did not find a universal property for itâ€”which is an abstract description of the object that determines it uniquely up to isomorphism, usually in terms of how it relates to other objects. Recently Awodey found a 1-dimensional universal property, which was the starting point of our work. What Andrew and I wanted to do is generalise Awodeyâ€™s analysis in two directions:

html:ol.html:li: We wanted a 2-dimensional version, which is useful because it captures more about the universe than can be said in just one dimension: for example, with a 2-dimensional version, you can see immediately (by â€œabstract nonsenseâ€) that Hofmannâ€“Streicher lifting preserves structures like monads, adjunctions, etc. that might be used for modelling computational effects, etc.

We wanted a relative version, which would make it easier to iterate the Hofmannâ€“Streicher lifting construction: the purpose of this is to be able to define presheaf models of type theory internal to other presheaf models. These kind of situations actually happen in practice! For example, the model of guarded cubical type theory that combines step-indexing with univalence ought to be an example of this.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To develop this two-fold generalisation of Hofmannâ€“Streicher lifting, we resituated the theory in terms of another of Thomasâ€™s favourite topics: the theory of fibrations, on which Thomas had written the most wonderful lecture notes.
We dedicated our paper to Thomasâ€™s memory. May he rest in peace.
